ildoc.introduction: This guide describes various low-level parts of .NET framework. Big attension is given to Common Inermediate Language syntax, metadata and instruction-set.

formatting.introduction: This section describes formatting and regular expressions (syntax grammar) used in this CLI Quick reference guide.

dl.dd: Code is anything that originates from the CIL language including regular expressions (syntax definitions) and .NET type names.
This is used in regular expressions (syntax definitions) to mark element (terminal or non-terminal) being declared elsewhere. It is also used to mark variables explained immediatelly below.
Reference to note is never formated as code. This way it is possible to distinguish when asterisk (*) is part of regular expression and when it is reference to note. Compare * and *.

Regular expressions for syntax definitions are losely based on .NET reguler expressions and grammar used for CLI grammas pecification. These expressions are not meant to be machine-readable, so some improvements towards human readability have been done possibly preventing those expressions from beingin machine-interpretable or unambignously defined.

Any text which appears in regular expression is treated as string-literal (as-is) with exception of *, +, ?, (, ), [, ], \, |. Dot (.) is treated as special character only when followed by *, ?, + or { or inside []. { and } are treated as special characters only if used as specified below. ,, - and ^ are treated as special character only in contexts specified below. Whitespaces in expressions are ignored or not depending on context. Usually sequnce of whitespaces is treated as any number opf any whitespaces. Sometimes whitespaces can be used instead of braces - see below.
Any number of occurences
a* matches '', 'a', 'aa', 'aaa' etc.
Any number of occurences other than no occurence.
a+ matches 'a', 'aa', 'aaa' etc.
Zero or one occurence
a? matches '' and 'a'
Exactly n occurences
a{3} matches 'aaa'
Mininally m, maximally n occurences
a{1,3} matches 'a', 'aa' and 'aaa'
Matches block of CIL code enclosed in {}. Allowd code in block is specified in this guide.
Flag-or. One or more elements of set can be used any any order without repetitions.
{a|b|c} matches '', 'a', 'b', 'c', 'ab', 'ba', 'ac', 'ca', 'bc', 'cb', 'abc', 'acb', 'bac', 'cab', 'cba'.
Classical braces
(ab)+ matches 'ab', 'abab' etc.
More meanings:
Trated this way only when cointains not-escaped - and does not contain not-escaped |.
Inside group specifier only -, ], | and ^ are treated as special characters.
[A-Zů] matches 'A', 'B', 'C', ..., 'Z' and 'ů'.
[A-Z]+ matches 'A', 'B', 'AB', 'GAG', 'HUIGG'.
In case [ is immediatelly followed by ^. Does not have to contain not-escaped - and can contain not-escaped |. Only -, ] and ^ are treated as special-characters inside inverted group specifier.
[^c-ek] does not match 'c', 'd', 'e', 'k'.
In case it does not contain not-escaped -, does not begin with ^ and is followed by one of quantifiers *, +, ?, {}.
[a]* matches '', 'a', 'aa' etc.
In case it does not start with ^ and contains non-escaped |.
Note that usage of | inside [] slightly differs from its usage outside it or inside (). In [] it behaves like if it has whitespace on both sides even if it does not have them.
[aaa|bbb] has same meaning as (aaa | bbb) what has same meaning as ((aaa)|(bbb)) and it has same meaning as [aaa | bbb]. It matches 'aaa' or 'bbb'.
In all other cases
[ab] matches '' or 'ab'.
Escape character
\* matches '*', \\ matches \, \a matches a
Universal character - matches any single character, but onyl when followed by one of quantifiers *, ?, + or {}.
.? matches '', '.', 'a', 'Ω' etc.
Or - matches contruct on left side or construct on right side.
When specified withoud whitespaces minimal contruct on side without whitespace is taken (typically one letter).

When specified with whitespace maximal construct on site eith whitespace is take. Maximal construct lookup is broken only by reaching scope boundary from inside at same level where | was used. Scope boundaries are introduced by whole expression itself, (), [] and {|} but {|} is irrelevant because | inside {} has slightly different meaning.
Note that inside [] | has different behavior (regarding whitespaces around it) then when not in [] - inside [] it always behaves like having whitespace on each side.
bye|hi matches 'byei' or 'byhi'.
bye | hi matches 'bye' or 'hi'.

section.introduction: This section describes common terms and abbreviations used in connection with .NET Framework.

dl.dd: The instruction set understood by the VES.
A specification for the format of executable code and runtime environment that can execute the code.
dl.dt: An agreement between language designers and framework (class library) designers. It specifies subset of the CTS and set of usage conventions.
dl.dd: A unified type system that is shared by compilers, tools, and the CLI itself. It is the model that defines the rules the CLI follows when declaring, using, and managing types. The CTS establishes a framework that enables cross-language integration, type safety, and high performance code execution.

This system implements and enforces the CTS model. The VES is responsible for loading and running programs written for the CLI. It provides the services needed to execute managed code and data using the metadata to connect separately generated modules together at runtime. The VES is also known as the Execution Engine.

section.introduction: This section describes syntactical elements used in CIL code.

dl.dd: Inegral number in decimal or hexadecimal format. CIL recognizes only 32-bit and 64-bit integral literals. In case 8-bit or 16-bit literal is required, appropriate high part of 32-bit literal is used.
Real number literal differes from integer literal by having decimal point and/or exponent.

Additionally real number can by entered by static cast from integral number or by byte representation. Byte representation is useful for values NaN, +∞ and -∞ when ilasm implementation does not support entering NaN, Inf and -Inf directly.
String value in double quotes ("). Exact behavior of excape character \ is implementation-dependent. Used for string literals.
String value in single quotes ('). Exact behavior of escape character \ is implementation dependent. Used for indentifiers containign special characters.
Identifier without special characters. _, $, @, ` and @ are not considered special characters.
Identifier can be either ID or SQSTRING.
Syntactical shortcut allowing to use names containing dots (.) without single quotes (').
One byte represented by hexadecimal number (without leading hexa-specifier)
Byte array is list of hexadecimally writtent bytes seperated by spaces.
Generic parameter specification
Simplified reference to type. E.g. allows use System.GC instead of .class System.GC
Reference to user-defined type

dd.code: !Int32 | !!Int32 | bool | char | class TypeReference | floa32 | float64 | int8 | int16 | int32 | int64 | method CallConv Type \* \([Param [, Param]*]\) | native int | native unsigned int | object | string | Type& | Type\* | Type<Type [, Type]* [,]*> | Type \[[(... | Int32 | Int32 ... | Int32 ... Int32) [, (... | Int32 | Int32 ... | Int32 ... Int32)]*]\] | Type modopt \(TypeReference\) | Type modreq \(TypeReference\) | Type pinned | typedref | valuetype TypeReference | unsigned int8 | unsigned int16 | unsigned int32 | unsigned int64 | void

dl.dd: Complex type reference

dd.code:
\[\] | bool | float32 | float64 | [unsigned] int | [unsigned] int8 | [unsigned] int16 | [unsigned] int32 | [unsigned] int64 | lpstr | lpwstr | method | NativeType \[\] | NativeType\[Int32\] | NativeType \[\+ Int32\] | NativeType \[Int32 \+ Int32\] |
(as any | byvalstr | custom \(QSTRING,QSTRING\) | fixed array [Int32] | fixed sysstring [Int32] | lpstruct | lpstr | struct)
[instance [explicit]] (default | unmanaged cdecl | unmanaged fastcall | unmanaged stdcall | unmanaged thiscall | vararg)

dl.dd: Manner of method calling
Method parameter definition

section.introduction: This section describes semantics of some elements introduced in General syntactical constructs. Selected non-trivial elements are described in-dept and single parts of those elements are discussed.
Complex reference to type.
section.p: Can be one of following values:

dl.dd: Reffres generic parameter from type declaration accessible by 0-based index.
Reffres generic parameter from method declaration accessible by 0-based index.
Built-in types
Reference to user*defined type. See TypeReference.
Method pointer. See CallConv.
Managed pointer to given type. Type cannot be managed pointer or typedref. Managed pointer is reported to garbage collector.
Unmanaged pointer to given type. Unmanaged pointer is not reported to garbage collector and behaves like unsigned integral number.
Generic type instance. Generic parameter cannot be: Managed pointer (ByRef); type field of which points to CIL evaluation stack (like ); void. Partial instantiation is not allowed.
Array. Several array declarations are possible.
So-called vactor - one dimensional 0-based array Vectors have special support in CIL - structrions newarr, ldelem, stelem or stelema. Vectors are subclasses of the class.
Array are defined by number of its dimensions. Each dimension is defined by boundaries Bound - it can be:
Lower bound and upper bound undefined.
Lower bound 0 and uppper bound given number.
Only lowe bound specified
Both bounds specified
Those arrays are supported by VES as subclasses of the class.
It as possible to created arrays of arrays, too.
User modifier (optional modifier) which is not required to be understood by caller.
User modifier (required modifier) which is required to be understood by caller.

Modifiers are something like user-attributes, but are part of signature. Each modifier associates reference to type with signature item. CLI treats required and optional modifiers same way. Two signatures that differ only by user modifiers are considered to be different. User modifiers has no meaning for VES. The fact that modifier is required or optional is meaningful to tools other than CLI (like alalyzers or compilers), which decides wheather modifier has any semantics they have to understand to.
Can be used only with local variables of methods.
In case method in which variable of pinned type is declared is being executed, VES cannot move the object which variable is reference to.
In case unmanaged pointers to managed objects are used, such object should be declared as pinned.
Reference to type (i.e. ) created by mkrefany. Used by instructions refanytype and refanyval.
User-defined value-type (structure) - not boxed.
No type. Allowed only as return type of method or as part of definition opf unmanaged pointer void*.

section.introduction: Reference to user-defined type.

dl.dd: If absent this reference is reference to same module of same assembly.
Reference to another module of same assembly.
Name of file containing the module. It must be module of same assembly.
Reference to another assembly
Name of referenced assembly defined using .assembly extern {}.
Type name. Slash is used to delimit name of containing type and nested type.

section.introduction: Simplified type reference
section.p: TypeSpec allows to use Type, TypeReference and syntactical shortcut \[[.module] DottedName\] in same place. So, it is possible e.g. instead of class System.GC use only System.GC.

section.introduction: Specifies a generic parameter.

dl.dd: Covariant generic parameter

Covariance means that when we have type IA<+T>, value of type IA`<A> can be assigned to target of type IA`<B> as long as it is possible to assgn value of type A to target of type B. For example following pseudo-code would be OK:
Covariant generic parameters can be used as method return types and can be used for creating covariant method return types.

example.code-ml: interface IEnumerator<+T> { T Current {get;} bool MoveNext(); } interface IEnumerable<+T> { IEnumerator<T> GetEnumerator(); }

dl.dd: Contravariant generic parameter
Contravariance if compagnon to covariance. Having type IB<-T> we can do assignment IB`1<B> := IB`1<A> as long as assignment A := B is possible.
Contravarian generic parameters can be used as method parameters types and can be used for constructing contravariant interfaces.

example.code-ml: interface IComparer<-T> { bool Compare(T x, T y); } interface IKeyComparer<-T> : IComparer<T> { bool Compare(T x, T y); int GetHashCode(T obj); }

dl.dd: Contravariant generic parameter can be used only in place of producer, reader or getter.
B → A ⇒ I<+B> → I<+A>
B → A ⇒ I<-A> → I<-B>
+ and - cannot be used simultaneously. In case none of them is used generic parameter is called non-variant. There are no restrictions for using non-variant generic parameters.
Covariance and contravariance can be used only with delegates and interfaces.
Generic parameter must be of type class (reference) not structure (value).
Generic parameter must be of value type (structure, not class - reference type), but cannot be System.Nullable<T>.
Restrictions class and valuetype shall not be combined.
Type parameter must be non-abstract class (reference type) with public constructor without parameters (default constructor) or it must be structure (value type).
Each of attributes +, -, class, valuetype and .ctor can be used maximally once.

Specifies restriction types for generic parameter. Type passed to generic parameter have to implement or inherit all listed types (so it makes sence to list maximally one class and several interfaces - no structures or delegates). Type passed to generic parameter might also be constraint type itself.
Name of generic parameter.

section.introduction: Defines which way the method is called.
section.syntax: [instance [explicit]] [default | unmanaged cdecl | unmanaged fastcalll | unmanaged stdcall | unmanaged thiscall | vararg]

dl.dd: This call is call of instance method (other possibility is static method). Pointer to current instance (so-called this-pointer) is passed to method.

This class of instance method uses explicitly passed this-pointer. Normally this-pointer is not part of argument list of method call, because it can be obtained from context. In case of explicit call first item of parameter list is this pointer.
Default way of calling managed methods. It shall be used always for managed method, unless vararg is required.
Call used by standard C language.
Call used by standard C++ language.
Special optimized way of calling used by C++.
C++ call with this-pointer.
Method accepts more arguments

section.p: Theoretically 16 different calling conventions can be encoded. 2 of them are used for managed calling kinds, 4 are resrved with defined meaning across platforms (as specified above). 4 more are reserved for existing calling conventions which are not maximally portable, 4 are reserved for future use by the standard and 2 are available for non-standard or experimental use.

section.introduction: Represents parameter of method.

dl.dd: Optinal name of the parameter. Parameters can be referenced by their names or 0-based indexes. To binary code the reference is lways translated using the index.
Marks parameter as input
Marks parameter as output
in and out can be used only for pointer types (both - managed and unmanaged). If neither of them is specified, in is assumed. CLI does not verify if parameters are used in declared direction only.
Marks parameter as optional (from end-user point-of-view). Default value is stored using the .param directive.
Parameters in, out and opt are not part of method signature.
Type of the parameter
Type used when passing the parameter to unmanaged code.

section.introduction: Describes platform-native types of platform .NET runs on.
section.syntax: \[\] | bool | float32 | float64 | [unsigned] int | [unsigned] int8 | [unsigned] int16 | [unsigned] int32 | [unsigned] int64 | lpstr | lpwstr | method | NativeType\[\] | NativeType\[Int32\] | NativeType\[+Int32\] | NativeType\[+Int32\+Int32\] | ( as any | byvalstr | custom \(QSTRING,QSTRING\) | fixed array [Int32] | fixed sysstring [Int32] | lpstruct | lpstr | struct )
section.p: Those are native types of platforms where .NET framework runs. In description below, in braces, value from the enumeration.

dl.dd: Native array. Type and size are determined in runtime.
Boolean - 4B integer, where 0 means false and anything else true.
4-byte floating point number
8-byte floating point number
(Un)signed iteger as big as native pointer of current platform.
(Un) signed integer of given size.
Pointer to nullchar-terminated string of ANSI characters. Codepage is implementation-dependent.
Pointer to nullchar-terminated string of Unicode characters. Encoding is implementation-dependent.
Pointer to function
Array of native type, size is determined in runtime.
Array of native type with specified lenght

Array of native type with item lenght specified in runtime. Int32 specifies 0-based index of parameter of current method, which in runtime contains size of array element in bytes. This can be applied only onto methods (not noto fields).

dd.ms-specific: In case the method has PreserveSig bit set to 1, parameter index is 1-based.

dl.dd: Array of native type with item lenght specified in runtime. 1st Int32 specifies number of array elements, 2nd Int32 specifies 0-based index of parameter of current method, which in runtime contains size of array element in bytes. This can be applied only onto methods (not noto fields).

dd.ms-specific: In case the method has PreserveSig bit set to 1, parameter index is 1-based.
Type of the object is determined at runtime

Custom marshaling. 1st QSTRING is name of class of marshaller (uses the same convention as Reflection.Emit to determine assembly and/or module). 2nd QSTRING is string passed to the marshaler in runtime to identify way of marshaling.
System-specific fixed-size string. Can be used only onto fields. Encoding is determined by special attribute.
Pointer to C-style structure. Used to marshal managed formatted types.
Pointer to nullchar-terminated platform-specific. (ANSI or Unicode) characters. Codepage is platform-dependent.
C-style strucrure. Used for marshaling managed formatted types.

section.introduction: Shows all the CIL metadata directives and way they relate one to each other.
Describes directives which can contain another directives or code.
Defines an assembly.
section.p: An assembly is specified as module that contains a manifest metadata. Manifest information is composed from .assembly {}, .assembly extern {}, .corflags, .file, .hash, .entrypoint, .mresource and .subsystem. The .assembly {} directive declares the manifest and specifies the assembly the current module belongs to. Module shall contain maximally one .assembly {} directive.
Since some platforms treat names in a case-insensitive manner, two assemblies that have names that differ only in case should not be declared.

section.introduction: Defines a reference to another assembly.

syntax-dl.dd: A name of a referenced assembly. It must equal to the name of referenced assembly as specified in that assembly using the .assembly {} directive.
A name of a referenced assembly uased when referenced from current assembly. This allows to reference more assemblies with same name but different version or culture.

section.p: Assembly names (for this purpose) are case-seinsitive even under OS with case-insensitive file system.

p.ms-specific: ilasm does not require .assembly extern mscorlib. It inserts in automatically.

section.introduction: Defines a class (or a structure or a delegate or an interface)

syntax-dl.dd: Class attributes sepeared with whitespaces. From syntactical point-of-view it's possible to use same attribute more than once.

dl.dd: Abstract (VB: MustInherit) class. It's impossible to create instance of abstract class. In case the class contains an abstract method it must be declared abstract.
The class that canno be derived (VB: NotInheritable).
The class that is abstract and sealed at same time should contain only static members (like standard modules in VB).
Use ANSI encoding for passing strings between managed and unmanaged code.
Automatically select encoding (according to platform) to be used when passing strings between managed and unmanaged code.
Use Unicode encoding when passing strings between managed and unmanaged code.
ansi, autochar and unicode define string marshaling from/to unmanaged code. Cannot be combined. Default value is ansi.
Let CLI to align instance fields in memory as it wishes.
CLI will align instance fields in memory as stated for individual fields. Not allowed for generic types.
CLI will align instance fields sequentially as they appear in metadata table.
auto, explicit and sequential define alignment of instance fields of the class in memory. Cannot be combined. Default value is auto.
Defines that the class is an interface.
Nested type acessible only from the assembly it's defined in (VB: Friend).

Nested type acessible only from the assembly it's defined in and within that assembly only from types derived from containing typ. This is AND-combination of nested assembly and nested familly. (VB: not available).
Netsed type accessible only from types derived from containing type (VB: Protected).
Nested type accessible from assembly where it is defined or from types derived from containing type. This is OR-combination of nested assembly and nested family (VB: Protected Friend).
Nested type accessible only from containing type (VB: Private)
Nested type accessible everywhere where containing type is accessible (VB: Public)
Non-nested type accessible only from assembly it's defined in (VB: Friend)
Non-nested type visible from anywhere.

nested ..., private and public defines class visibility (accessibility). Only one of them can be used. In case of classes defined inside classes one of nested ... modifiers must be used. In case of classes defined at assembly level (top-level) private or public must be used. Default visibility for top-level classes is public. Default visibility for nested classes is nested private.
Instructs CLI to initialize static fields of type before first call to any static method of that type.
Indicates that type name has special meaning for CLI. Currently there are no special names of types defined. In case rtspecialname is used specialname must be used as well.
reserved for future use.
Reserved for future use. It'll mean that fields are serialised to data stream. Serialization support will provided by CLI implementation.
Indicates that type name has special meaning for tools other than CLI.

dd.ms-specific: The type is imported from COM library

syntax-dl.dd: The type this the class derives from. When ommited is assumed.
Comma-separeted list ot types (interfaces) this class implements

section.introduction: New types are defined by defining custom classes. New types can be also defined as generic instances, arrays, vectors or pointers. This sub-chapter describes types declared using the .class {} directive.

dl.dd: Reference types are basic kind of types in CLI. Each reference type derives from or from class derived from (with exception of special-purpose classes - see below). No additional restrictions applies for reference types.
Reference types are passed by reference when passed to methods, returned from methods or assigned to fields.

Interface is special abstract type defined by the interface attribute. An interface can be implemebted by either reference or value type. To implement an interface a class must implement all abstract methods of the interface or derive from a class which implements them. An exception is an abstract class which don't need to implement (all) those abstract methods, because instance of an abstract class cannot be created. Interface methods not implemented by an abstract class must be implemented in a non-abstract class derived from such abstract class.
An interface can contain any static members (fields, methods etc.). All instance methods of interfaces must be virtual and abstract. Interfaces cannot have instance fields.

It's not enough for an interface to be implemented by a type to implement all interface methods. It must be explicitly stated for the type that it implements the interface (the implements clause of the .class {} directive. In case a class implements an interface which requires implementation of another interface it's enough for class to specify implementation of of the more-specific of both interfaces (the derived one).
Interface can specify that it requires implementation of other interface(s) - derives from it/them. (Technically it's not that an interface derives other interface(s) - it implements them.)
For a method to implement a method of an interface following options are available:
Class method has same name and signature as interface method.
Existing implementation of an interface is derived from base class.
Uisng MethodImpl - the .override directive.

The documentation does not deal with interface-level properties and events. From practical usage we can deduce that same rules as for method applies. Also note that properties and events are in fact only groups of related methods.

Value types are not passed as reference but as contents of memory (they are copied when passed!). Value types should be used for storing small amount of data. Higher languages represents them as structures (while reference types are represented as classes). Relation between value and reference type in CLI is similat to relation between structure and pointer to structure in C++. Typical value types are complex number, date etc.
Each value type can be easily transformed to corresponding reference type by a process called boxing. Such boxed value type can be converted back to value type by a process of unboxing.
Each value type must be sealed (it cannot be derived from) and it's base class must be either or .
A value type can implement interfaces(s), but such implementation can be utilized only in boxed form.

Value of non-boxed value type cannot be null and cannot be compared to null. Value types are not treated as instances of other types, so the isints instruction cannot be used with them (it can be used with boxed value type).
Item layout of value types can be controlled in the same way as in reference types. It's usefull when comunicationg with native code.

Value type can contain neither field of type of itself nor field of type of value type which contains field of that type (value type cannot directly or indirectly contain field of type itself - it would lead to allocation of infinite memory).

Instance methods of value types obtains managed pointer to current instance to the this variable (while in reference types the this variable contains directly tha value of the refernce type - so a reference).
Enumerations are used to define set of symbols of the same value type. CLI does not guarantee that value of variable of enum type is one of enum items.
A type can be an enumeration only when it derives form .

Only fields are allowed as members of enumerations. An enumeration cannot implement any interface and must have auto layout. An enumeration must have exactly one instance member field whose type determines enumeration sub-type. The other member fields must be static literals not initialized using the initobj instruction. Type of these variables is the enumeration itself and their values are stored in metadata using FieldInit (see .field).
There is a direct conversion in both directions between enumerated type and its subtype.
A delegate is managed equivalent of method pointer (CLI supports method pointers as well).
A delegate is a sealed reference type, which directly or indirectly derives from (delegates derive from )

Delegate can contain only first two or all four of methods below. These methods are runtime and managed and don't have body specified - it's provided automatically by VES. Other method which can be called on delegate types are inherited from base class.

Delegate instance constructor. It has exactly two parameters - and . The first one represents instance of class declaring the method delegate points to (pass null for static methods) and the other is pointer to that method.
A virtual method used to invoke method represented by this delegate. The signature of this method is same as signature of the delegate points to.
Optional. Compulsory when EndInvoke is present.
A virtual method used to call the delegate asynchronously. It has signature similar to Invoke. It's return type is . It has all the parameters Invoke has plus two more of types and .
Optional. Compulsory when BeginInvoke is present.
A virtual method with the same return type as Invoke. It contains those of parameters of Invoke method which are of type managed pointer (in same order) and after them last parameter of type .
Unless stated otherwise, a standard delegates provide all four methods.

dd.ms-specific: Delegates can contain additional methods, in case programmer provides their implementation (i.e. methods are not runtime). In such case the assembly is not portable.

section.introduction: Used in manifest module (note: there can be only one manifest module in each assembly). This directive defines a type exported (visible from) outside the assembly which is actually defined in different module of the assembly. Types defined in same module as assembly manifest are not required to be exported this way.

syntax-dl.dd: Visibility attribute of the export. It must be same as visibility of type being exported.

section.introduction: Represents data inserted to PE file.
Defines an event.

syntax-dl.dd: When specified means that name of the event has special meaning to tools other than CLI.
When specified means that name of the event has special meaning to CLI.
There are currently no names with special meaning to CLI defined.
If present identifies the delegate type whose signature is same as signature of method for firing the event (fire).

section.introduction: Defines a method (function, procedure, constructor, accessor, operator, etc.)
section.syntax: .method MethAttr* [CallingConvention] [\[in\] | \[opt\] | \[out\]]* ReturnType [marshall \([ReturnMarshalling]\)] Name [<GenPar [, GenPar]*>] \([Parameter [, Parameter]*]\) ImplAttr* {}

syntax-dl.dd: Attributes of the method. Following values are possible:

dl.dd: An abstract method. An abstract method must be virtual as well. An abstract method does not contain implementation - it's provided by derived type. Only abstract types can contain abstract methods. (VB: MustOverride)

The method gets a new slot in virtual methods table. It gets it always, even where there is method with same name and signature in a base class. In case this attribute is not specified a method gets a new slot in virtual methods table only in case there's not method with same name and signature in a base class. (VB: Shadows, not specified - Overrides; C#: new)
Indicates that virtual method cannot be overriden in derived class (VB: NotOverridable). Final method must be virtual.

The method hides method with same name and signature from base class. In case this attribute is ommited current method hides all methods of base class(es) with same name not comparing signature. VES does not control or verify this. This is feature for tools (i.e. compilers).

VB: In case this attribute is ommited and the method is virtual it's marked as Shadows in Visual Basic, but Shadows in Visual Basic hides also members of different type than method (fields, events, types, etc.).
See also newslot.
A method is static (not instance) (VB: Shared)
A method is virtual (can be overriden in derived class) (VB: Overridable)
Check method accessibility when overriding it. Must be virtual.

section.introduction: Describes directives single-line directives.
